answers: M. R. James [or Montague Rhodes James; prompt on James]
parts: Name this W. W. Jacobs story which ends with a painful cry from Mrs. White as she opens the front door to greet her mutilated son Herbert.

Some of England's most chilling ghost stories were written by this author of Ghost Stories of an Antiquary, whose stories often involve an academic who invokes the wrath of a spirit, as in "The Mezzotint".
This author parodied the ghost story in a work whose characters refuse to believe that a ghost inhabits Canterville Chase. His other Gothic works include The Picture of Dorian Grey.

answers: Romney [accept George Wilcken Romney or Willard Mitt Romney]
Kerner Commission [or National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders]
parts: Detroit experienced destructive race riots in its 12th Street during the "long, hot summer" of what year?
As Governor of Michigan, a politician with this surname called in the National Guard during the riots. His son was a former governor of Massachusetts and 2012 Republican presidential candidate.
Lyndon Johnson created this commission to investigate the causes of the 1967 race riots. It reported that "our nation is moving toward two societies, one black, one white — separate and unequal".
To speed up the backlog, you integrate the "unit" form of this process into practices to help check if the neg prediction code is working. Unfortunately, Hari negs 100 times to break the system.
Luckily for you, GT Quizbowl uses this adaptive planning development approach popularized in a namesake manifesto that emphasizes flexibility and continual iteration.
Since GT kids are visual learners, you use this lean method borrowed from the automotive industry, which limits in-progress work and visualizes backlogs on a namesake board.

answers: horse sacrifice [accept any answer which refers to killing a horse; accept "stallion" or "mare" in place of "horse"; accept ashvamedha; prompt on October Horse or Equus October; prompt on animal sacrifice; do not accept or prompt on answers explicitly mentioning any non-horse animal]
Ireland [or Éire; accept Ulster or Ulaidh; accept Tyrconnell or Tír Chonaill; accept County Donegal or Contae Dhún na nGall]
parts: Identify these events performed to honor Mars during a festival on October 15. In Vedic India, one was done at the end of a year-long roaming period to confirm a king's rule.
Greeks preserved a memory of funerary horse sacrifices in the Iliad's account of the funeral of this lover of Achilles who was killed by Hector.
Giraldus writes that new rulers of a kingdom in this European region had sex with a mare that was then dismembered and cooked in a cauldron. This region's High Kings were crowned at Tara.

answers: Charles Sanders Peirce (That essay is "How to Make Our Ideas Clear.")
parts: In standard Boolean logic, numbers can only take on these two values, which indicate "True" and "False".

This American philosopher's system of three-valued logic uses the symbols V, L, and F to indicate values of "True," "Indeterminate," and "False". In an essay for Popular Science, he proposed that logic should aim at "clearness of apprehension".
This Azerbaijani logician and mathematician developed what he called "fuzzy logic," a generalization of Boolean logic which allows any intermediate value between 0 and 1, to represent vagueness.

answers: The Heart is a Lonely Hunter
parts: Name this character who visits a ten-cent shop to get his photo taken after pay days at the jewelry store. He becomes a kleptomaniac and starts urinating in public after recovering from a stomach problem.
Spiros Antonapoulos dies in an asylum in this novel. Its original title, The Mute, refers to its protagonist John Singer, who commits suicide after learning of Spiros's death.
The Heart is a Lonely Hunter is by this Georgia-born Southern Gothic author of The Ballad of the Sad Cafe.

answers: ladder operators [accept both the raising and lowering operators, accept both the creation and annihilation operators]
quantum harmonic oscillators [accept simple harmonic oscillators, accept QHO or SHO]
parts: Name these quantities, which are used in the so-called "algebraic method" to factor a Hamiltonian given by (pause) p squared over 2m, (pause) plus m times omega squared times x squared, where omega is the angular frequency.
The ladder operators allow one to elegantly compute the ground state energy of the "quantum" version of these systems, whose restoring force is given by Hooke's Law.
Multiplying the raising operator on the right by the lowering operator gives this operator, which acts on a state to return the energy level the state is in.

Name this genre of music whose standards include "Chega da Saudade" ("SHEH-gah dah sau-DAH-jee"), which was written by João Gilberto ("zhuh-WOW zheel-BAIR-too"). Its other standards include "Desafinado" ("des-AH-fee-NAH-doo").
Accompanists in bossa nova songs often play this instrument without a plectrum. A "Portuguese" variety of this instrument that is pear-shaped consists of 12 steel strings.
Bossa nova is often compared to this expressive, melodic genre of Portuguese vocal music, whose typically sad themes are similar to those of Brazilian choros ("SHOW-roos").

answers: Chin Peng [or Ong Boon Hua; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this present-day country where communist forces fought the British Empire during a namesake "emergency". So-called "New Villages" were created to relocate Chinese immigrants in this country.
General Harold Briggs approved the use of this chemical to destroy jungles during the Malayan Emergency. It was more famously used in the Vietnam War.
This leader of the Malaysian Communist Party instigated the Malayan Emergency. He had earlier assisted Freddie Spencer Chapman in fighting the Japanese in Malaysia's jungles.

answers: Old Maid [do not reveal this answer otherwise, but prompt on Black Peter]
Black Peter [or Zwarte Piet; prompt on Peter or Pete]
Jack of Spades [or knave of spades; or valet of spades; prompt on jack or knave or valet by asking "of what suit?"] (This is why the game is called "jackass" in some countries.)
parts: Give the common American name of this card game in which players continually play pairs of cards until one is left with the card representing the namesake woman in their hand.

A variant of "Old Maid" in Europe is often named for this soot-covered helper of Santa Claus. Many activists have protested the Dutch tradition of people donning blackface to depict this man in parades.

In many variants of Black Peter, the namesake character is represented by this playing card. In some decks, this playing card depicts Ogier ("oh-zhee-AY"), a legendary knight from Charlemagne's court.
Name this composer who used a constant snare drum ostinato in his piece Boléro.
This composer, whose Diversions for Piano Left Hand and Orchestra are also for Wittgenstein, adapted a rondeau from Purcell's Abdelazer for another of his pieces.

The movement "with fire and power" ends this Austrian composer's C-sharp major Piano Concerto for the Left Hand for Wittgenstein. He wrote the opera Die tote Stadt ("dee TOH-tuh SHTAHT") before fleeing to Hollywood to write film scores.

answers: London School of Economics [or LSE, or The London School of Economics and Political Science]
parts: Name this British socialist who coined the term "collective bargaining". She and her husband were key leaders of the Fabian Society.

The Webbs and other Fabians used an endowment from Henry Hutchinson's legacy to found this institution, which is often grouped with Oxford and Cambridge as the "golden triangle" of British research universities.
Among the faculty that the Webbs recruited to LSE was this Polish-born anthropologist who wrote Argonauts of the Western Pacific.
Unions such as the CNT exemplify the merger of this ideology with anarchism. This ideology advocates that labor unions use strikes for workers to seize the means of production.
The CNT was founded following a 1910 workers' congress in this city. A 1909 general strike resulted in the "Tragic Week" in this capital of Catalonia.

One of the CNT's biggest victories came when a power company in Barcelona, which was named for being located in this country, lowered the length of the work day to eight hours following a 1919 strike.

answers: poetic feet [or metrical feet; accept foot for "feet"]
Serbs [or Serbians, or Srbi; accept Croats; accept Serbo-Croatians or Serbo-Croatians or Hrvatska; prompt on Slavs or Slavic people or South Slavs; do not accept or prompt on "Balkans"]
parts: The theory argues that epithets, such Homer's "rosy-fingered dawn," served as these devices to help poets recall names. Their name comes from the Greek for "memory".

The theory argues that using a fixed number of these metric units per line helped poets remember lines. Typically, these units consist of one stressed and one unstressed syllable, so five are in a line of iambic pentameter.
The theory was inspired by Milman Parry's studies of this ethnic group's epics, such as The Building of Skadar, which are performed by bards on the gusle ("GOO-leh").

answers: dissociation constant [or Kd; prompt on equilibrium constant or K]
parts: Name this model, which can be derived from the steady-state approximation. The Hill equation reduces to this model when the Hill coefficient equals 1.
Michaelis-Menten kinetics models the rate of reactions that occur at the active sites of these substances.
For a solution of enzyme and ligand, when exactly half the enzymes are bound to a ligand, the concentration of free ligand must equal this value.

answers: Jambudvīpa [or Jambudweep; prompt on dvipa or dweep]
trees [accept jambu trees, jamun trees, blackberry trees, plum trees, fig trees, or fruit trees; accept Bodhi Tree]
parts: Name this "world-island" or "continent" where humans live in Jain and Hindu cosmology.

Some conceptions of Jambudvīpa consider it to be one of these objects, five of which are among the nine bodies called Navagraha. Like the Romans, Hindus named a red one of these objects for a god of war.
The name Jambudvīpa literally means "island of jamun," which is a variety of these objects. A descendant of a sacred one of these objects from Bodh Gaya is housed in the Mahabodhi temple.

answers: Akkadian empire [or Agade] (The unnamed ruler is Sargon the Great.)
Pharaoh of Egypt (The two pharaohs in the question are Menes and Ramesses the Great)
parts: Name this empire, which reached its greatest extent under Naram-Sin. One of its earlier rulers served as cup-bearer to Ur-Zababa of Kish.

Some chronicles describe Naram-Sin defeating Manium, often equated with a holder of this title, during his invasion of Magan. A later holder of this title won the Battle of Kadesh against the Hittites.
The fall of the Akkadian empire was blamed on these people from the Zagros Mountains. According to the Weidner Chronicle, Marduk summoned them twice to punish Naram-Sin.
Name this style of art which makes prominent use of distorted geometric forms. Its practitioners include Josef Albers.

Op art came to prominence after a MoMA exhibition of Riley's works titled for a "responsive" example of these objects. The French phrase trompe l'oeil ("tromp loy") refers to art that "deceives" these objects.
One of the earliest op-art works is a 1937 Victor Vasarely painting which shows two of these non-tiger animals overlapping against a black background.
Name this South African author of Cry, the Beloved Country.
In Cry, the Beloved Country, Father Vincent helps this priest, who earlier travels to Johannesburg. This man's son Absalom murders the liberal white man Arthur Jarvis.

After Stephen prays following Absalom's death, the novel concludes by speaking of this concept's "bondage". The passage that gives the novel its title, which follows Jarvis's death, describes the "unborn child" as the "inheritor" of this concept.

answers: cyano group [or cyanide; prompt on nitrile]
parts: Name this group, which serves as a nucleophile to help elongate an aldose in the Kiliani-Fischer synthesis.
Like most electron-withdrawing groups, cyano groups direct electrophilic aromatic substitutions to this position, which is two carbons away on a benzene ring.
An alkene with one cyano group attached to each carbon makes an excellent dienophile in this cycloaddition reaction, which forms cyclohexene derivatives.
